value: aava_1.0_score
description

The two metadata versions represent the same conceptual workflow model with significant structural reorganization and minor semantic evolution. AAVA 2.0 introduces hierarchical restructuring while preserving core business logic.
Core workflow concept preserved: Both versions define a 3-agent workflow for Informatica to PySpark conversion with documentation, analysis, and planning phases.
Agent purposes remain semantically identical across versions with consistent business objectives for data migration workflows.
Major structural reorganization: AAVA 1.0 uses flat 'nodes' array while AAVA 2.0 introduces nested 'workFlowDetail' and 'workflowAgents' hierarchy.
Workflow identification changed from simple integer 'workflowId' to structured object with 'id' and 'name' properties.
Field 'workflowId' (integer) renamed to 'workFlowDetail.id' (integer) - semantic meaning preserved but structural location changed.
Field 'workflowName' (string) renamed to 'workFlowDetail.name' (string) - semantic meaning preserved with structural reorganization.
Array 'nodes' renamed to 'workflowAgents' - semantic meaning preserved but implies more specific agent-focused terminology.
Agent property 'agentName' renamed to 'name' - simplified naming convention within agent context.
Agent property 'model' renamed to 'modelDeploymentName' - more descriptive and deployment-specific terminology.
Agent property 'tools' renamed to 'toolReferences' - more explicit about reference nature of tool associations.
Task structure completely flattened: AAVA 1.0 nested task object removed, description moved to agent level in AAVA 2.0.
Model specification enhanced: 'gpt-4' changed to 'gpt-4.1' indicating version upgrade in deployment configuration.
Agent identification added: AAVA 2.0 introduces 'agentId' field providing unique identifiers missing in AAVA 1.0.
Task structure simplified but potentially loses granular task metadata organization present in AAVA 1.0.
JSON structure valid with proper nesting and consistent data types throughout the document.
All required fields present with appropriate string and integer types for workflow and agent definitions.
JSON structure valid but introduces potential inconsistency with camelCase 'workFlowDetail' mixing conventions.
Missing 'expectedOutput' field in agent definitions that was present in AAVA 1.0 task structure.
Evolution represents modernization with improved agent identification and deployment-specific model naming.
Structural reorganization improves logical grouping but may impact backward compatibility for dependent systems.
Breaking change: Flat 'nodes' to nested 'workflowAgents' structure requires significant parsing logic updates in downstream systems.
Task metadata loss: Removal of explicit task object may impact systems expecting granular task-level configuration.
Field path changes require comprehensive mapping updates in analytics pipelines and governance tooling.
Inconsistent naming convention: 'workFlowDetail' uses mixed case while other fields follow camelCase pattern.
Content preservation: All agent descriptions and business logic remain identical between versions ensuring functional continuity.
Enhanced metadata: Addition of agentId provides better traceability and system integration capabilities.
Model versioning: Explicit version specification in modelDeploymentName improves deployment management.
